entry.title: Three months without Emacs: do I miss it?
entry.summary: Three months passed since I used Emacs for anything, here is what I miss (or don't)!
entry.content:
I used to do it all in Emacs, checking my email, chatting, reading news, planning tasks and even listening to internet radio and podcasts. I used spit a thousand commands per second with the amazing xah-fly-keys modal editing. I was very productive indeed, I didn't even launch X if I didn't needed to. In fact, I had a Nix script that built Emacs and it's packages together with my system stuff, it was basically Nix/Emacs! hehehe

Then, I narrowed my studies to Python and Data Science, and a graphical interface turned into something just so essential, then came Jupyter, and I bought a new computer which came with Windows... I felt I could try something really different to make my life more sane (because I try to do so many different things in life), and rather than just changing my Window Manager, I re-evaluated my whole toolset.

For most production stuff I used Emacs for, like to-do lists and calendar, I'm using Outlook now, synchronizing with my phone is always good. In fact, most non-programming things I did before now are done faster and more nicely (UX-wise) with office tools.

For Notebooks (my work tool as a data guy), EIN is good. But I got really used to Jupyter Lab, it's way easier to configure. I also like to use the Google Colab platform when I need to show someone the code (it makes a lot easier to share). In the R side, RStudio is just too good to ignore, it's like "Excel for serious math". Ok, this is like 4 different interfaces to learn, but once you get good at them, I think production goes up so much, and most of them are way easier to learn than Emacs. Maybe I'm just experiencing the universal facts of QWERTY Theory. I feel a lot more productive just not trying too hard.

The only thing I really miss Emacs is actually coding (this sounds silly!). I have been using the Atom editor, which looks like a good Emacs replacement, but I really could not dig too much into it. (Help! I don't see a RELP!) I miss coding modes for more hipster languages like the Hy Programming Language, which I love. I'll probably install Emacs soon to play with this language again, I just need to decide: MSYS, Cygwin, WSL... Maybe native?

entry.title: New computer, strange freezes and silly solution
entry.summary: I bought a new computer and it came with a weird bug that took me months to fix.
entry.content:
After enduring for 7 years, my Lenovo Ideapad S400 started to give up on me. It was my main and mostly only machine. I wished to buy a Thinkpad as an upgrade since I liked it so much, but with the whole COVID-19 crisis, the prices skyrocketed. I ended up buying an Acer Aspire 3 with AMD processor/video card, it was a more cost-effective choice than another Ideapad. I'm quite happy with it so far, and I'm enjoying being able to play some modern games.

But as soon as I got everything setup on the new machine, it started to freeze randomly. It would happen on random times, usually when I used a lot of RAM. It happened a lot of times when I was using Jupyter Kernels, and mostly when changing context from one application to another. The mouse wouldn't move, sound would glitch, all the system froze. I came to the point of reinstalling Windows 10 altogether two times, trying different driver versions and software to troubleshot the problem. I was praying for it not to be a factory defect since I could not afford not having a computer for work and study. The solution was quite surprising for me...

Two months of intensive testing and freezing and rebooting passed. I tried changing habits and not opening lots of programs and keeping them opened as I did previously. But what would be the point of having a newer, faster machine, then?

And then I searched for something I was sure it was NOT the problem, since I had used for my entire life and it has never failed me: Veracrypt. It turns out Veracrypt was just the cause of the problem. I had always used it's full disk encryption on Windows, but I used Windows 8 previously, and looks like with newer versions of Windows 10 it has a bug where the encryption keys end up in the paging file and deadlocking the system. You can find about it clicking on this thread.

So the solution was disabling full system encryption, encrypting only sensitive files (and using Window's native system encryption). Of course, I could always go back to Linux, or dual booting, but I'm enjoying what became of Windows 10. I'll sure write about my experience on another posts.

entry.title: Configuring the DVORAK International with dead keys AND DVORAK keyboards on X11
entry.summary: I have been using the DVORAK keyboard layout for years, and I'm really glad I did it, because it forced me to learn how to properly type. The problem comes when you want to input diacritics used in some languages (things like "Ãº" and "Ãµ"). My usual setup was: using â€¦
entry.content:
I have been using the DVORAK keyboard layout for years, and I'm really glad I did it, because it forced me to learn how to properly type. The problem comes when you want to input diacritics used in some languages (things like "Ãº" and "Ãµ"). My usual setup was: using setxkbmap to turn on the DVORAK keyboard and using something like SCIM/iBus to activate the "latin-pre" input method to suit my special characters needs. This seems like overkill and I was searching for an alternative.

It turns out that XFCE does change between keyboard layouts and has DVORAK and a DVORAK international keyboard with dead keys, and with no special input method needed at all. I was curious about how this happens (probably some X11 "system-agnostic" configuration) and wanted to make whatever this is to work on xmonad. After a quick search at my ".config" folder I found a "keyboard-layout.xml" file with all the keyboard configuration.

This is definitely what I was looking for. If you man setxkbmap, you see that there is a correspondence between the properties on the XML and the options for setxkbmap. So my setxkbmap command now looks like: setxkbmap -layout dvorak,us -variant ,dvorak-intl -option grp:alt_space_toggle and I can simply switch between DVORAK and DVORAK international using Alt + Space!
